title: Agent Chaining & Cascading
description: Using one agent's output as input for another to accomplish complex tasks

sections.heading: What is Agent Chaining?
content: Agent chaining is when you use the output from one AI agent as the input for another AI agent. It's like an assembly line where each agent does one specific job really well, then passes the work to the next agent.

Think about making a sandwich. You don't do everything at once. First, someone gets the bread. Then someone adds meat. Then someone adds vegetables. Then someone cuts it. Each person (or agent) does one thing well, and together they create something better than any single person could make alone.

benefits.title: Better Quality
benefits.description: Each agent specializes in one task. A research agent is better at research than a writing agent. A writing agent is better at writing than a design agent. Use each for what it does best.

benefits.title: Less Revision
benefits.description: When you try to do everything in one prompt, you often get mediocre results and spend hours revising. Chaining produces better first drafts because each step is optimized.

benefits.title: Reproducible Workflows
benefits.description: Once you build a chain that works, you can use it again and again. It becomes a repeatable process, not a one-time effort.

example.scenario: You have survey results and need an interactive website to share them

steps.task: Analyze the survey data and identify key insights, trends, and important findings
steps.output: A structured summary of findings with specific data points and visualizations needed

steps.task: Take the analysis and write clear, engaging content for the website
steps.output: Polished copy including headlines, descriptions, and data narratives

steps.task: Build an interactive website using the content and data
steps.output: A complete, deployed website with charts, tables, and responsive design

example.result: A professional website created in 30 minutes that would have taken 6-8 hours to build manually (40-50% time reduction, consistent with [research on AI writing productivity](https://www.science.org/doi/10.1126/science.adh2586))
example.timeSaved: Saved 5.5-7.5 hours compared to doing it yourself

sections.heading: How to Chain Agents
steps: Identify what you need to create (the final output)
Break it down into distinct steps that different agents do well
Start with the first agent and get its output
Copy that output and give it to the next agent with instructions
Repeat until you reach the final output
Save the chain as a workflow you can reuse

patterns.name: Analyze → Summarize → Visualize
patterns.use: Making sense of data and sharing insights

patterns.name: Ideate → Refine → Execute
patterns.use: Going from concept to finished product

example.scenario: You collected 200 community feedback forms and need to create a report for leadership

steps.task: Upload all feedback forms and ask: 'Analyze this community feedback. Identify the top 5 themes, key concerns, and actionable recommendations.'
steps.output: Structured analysis with themes, quotes, and recommendations

steps.task: Give it the analysis and say: 'Write an executive summary and detailed report based on this analysis. Make it professional and action-oriented.'
steps.output: Polished report with executive summary, findings, and recommendations

steps.task: Give it the report and say: 'Create an interactive web dashboard showing this community feedback analysis with charts and key findings.'
steps.output: Interactive website with visualizations and downloadable report

example.result: A comprehensive, professional report with interactive dashboard completed in 45 minutes that would normally take 8-12 hours manually (consistent with [Harvard/BCG research](https://www.hbs.edu/faculty/Pages/item.aspx?num=64700) showing 25% faster completion with AI)
example.timeSaved: Saved 7-11 hours of manual analysis, writing, and design work

tips.why: When passing output to the next agent, tell it exactly what you want it to do with that input. Don't assume it will figure it out.
Ask each agent to format its output in a way that's easy for the next agent to use (bullet points, tables, clear sections).
Check each agent's output before passing it to the next one. If something is off, fix it before it compounds.
Write down the sequence that works. Next time you need to do something similar, you'll have a proven workflow to follow.

callout.title: Your First Chain (20 minutes):
steps: Pick something you need to create this week (report, presentation, website, analysis)
Write down 3 steps: What needs to happen first? Second? Third?
Identify which AI agent is best for each step
Start with step 1: Give the first agent clear instructions
Take its output and give it to the second agent with instructions
Take that output and give it to the third agent
Review the final result - it should be 80-90% done
callout.footer: You just created something in 20 minutes that would have taken hours or days. That's the power of chaining.
